questions.text: A newborn is born to a mother with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. On examination, the infant exhibits cyanosis, tachypnea, and a loud, single second heart sound. What congenital heart defect is most commonly associated with infants of diabetic mothers (IDMs) and is likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA).
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most specific congenital heart defect associated with infants of diabetic mothers is Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) , characterized by cyanosis, tachypnea, and a loud, single second heart sound. The classic X-ray finding in TGA is the "egg on a string" appearance.
  • ➤ Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA)

questions.text: A newborn is born to a mother with pre-existing diabetes mellitus. The infant exhibits macrosomia, hypoglycemia, and respiratory distress shortly after birth. What is the most likely cause of hypoglycemia in infants born to diabetic mothers, and what is the recommended initial management?

options.label: B
options.text: Maternal hyperglycemia; Administer insulin to the newborn.

questions.correct_answer: C. Fetal hyperinsulinemia; Administer glucose infusion.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fetal hyperinsulinemia; Administer glucose infusion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In infants born to diabetic mothers, hypoglycemia is caused by fetal hyperinsulinemia due to maternal hyperglycemia. Immediate treatment involves glucose infusion to stabilize the newborn’s blood glucose levels.

questions.text: A term newborn is prescribed chloramphenicol for a suspected infection. Shortly after receiving the medication, the infant develops cyanosis, abdominal distension, and cardiovascular collapse. What is the likely diagnosis in this neonate, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: G6PD deficiency; Hemolysis triggered by chloramphenicol.

options.label: B
options.text: Meconium aspiration syndrome; Obstruction of the airways.

options.label: D
options.text: Transient tachypnea of the newborn; Delayed lung maturation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Gray baby syndrome; Chloramphenicol toxicity.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gray baby syndrome; Chloramphenicol toxicity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gray baby syndrome is a life-threatening reaction to chloramphenicol in neonates due to their immature drug-metabolizing enzymes. Early recognition and prompt discontinuation of the drug are critical.

questions.text: A term newborn develops seizures within the first few days of life. Initial workup shows no signs of infection or metabolic abnormalities. Phenobarbital is administered as an antiepileptic treatment. What is the primary mechanism of action of phenobarbital in managing seizures in neonates?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enhancement of GABAergic inhibition.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenobarbital is the drug of choice for neonatal seizures, and its primary mechanism of action is the enhancement of GABAergic inhibition , which decreases neuronal excitability and controls seizure activity.
  • ➤ enhancement of GABAergic inhibition

questions.text: A term newborn develops severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that is unresponsive to phototherapy and exchange transfusion. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of indirect bilirubin. What is the potential treatment option for this infant's refractory jaundice that targets the heme degradation pathway and inhibits bilirubin production?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metalloporphyrins (e.g., tin-mesoporphyrin).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metalloporphyrins, such as tin-mesoporphyrin, inhibit the heme oxygenase enzyme in the heme degradation pathway, making them an effective treatment for refractory unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in newborns.

questions.text: A term newborn with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia has not responded to phototherapy. Physical examination reveals hypertonia, arching of the back, and high-pitched crying. Which of the following brain regions is most susceptible to bilirubin-induced damage in this infant, potentially leading to kernicterus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basal ganglia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unconjugated bilirubin is the dangerous form that can cross the blood-brain barrier, primarily affecting the basal ganglia and leading to kernicterus.

questions.text: A pre-term newborn exhibits signs of respiratory distress shortly after birth, including grunting, nasal flaring, intercostal retractions, and cyanosis. On examination, you observe decreased chest movement and breath sounds. Which neonatal assessment tool is commonly used to evaluate the severity of respiratory distress in this newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Silverman-Anderson score

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Silverman-Anderson score is the gold standard for assessing respiratory distress severity in preterm newborns.

questions.text: A 28-week gestation preterm infant is at risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The neonatal team is considering administering antenatal steroids to the mother for fetal lung maturation. Which maternal condition represents a contraindication for the administration of antenatal steroids in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chorioamnionitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chorioamnionitis is a contraindication for antenatal steroid administration due to the risk of exacerbating maternal and fetal infection .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents to the obstetric clinic for a routine check-up. During the visit, she asks about the development of her baby's lungs. At what gestational age does surfactant production typically appears, leading to its appearance in the amniotic fluid and contributing to fetal lung maturity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 28 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surfactant production begins around 20-24 weeks but reaches detectable levels in the amniotic fluid by 28 weeks, with full maturity typically achieved by 33-35 weeks.

questions.text: A newborn is born and you are tasked with calculating the Apgar score at 1 minute after birth. The baby's heart rate is 160 bpm, respiratory effort is good with a strong cry, muscle tone is active, reflex irritability is vigorous when stimulated, and the baby's peripheries skin color is blue. What is the Apgar score for this newborn at 1 minute?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 9

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apgar score assesses newborn well-being at 1 and 5 minutes after birth. A score of 9 in this scenario reflects a healthy newborn with minor acrocyanosis.
  • ➤ acrocyanosis.

questions.text: A 1-day-old newborn presents with drooling, choking, and cyanosis during feeding. The infant has excessive oral secretions and experiences respiratory distress. An abdominal radiograph shows a coiled feeding tube in the proximal esophagus, while the distal esophagus ends in a blind pouch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) should be suspected in a newborn with drooling, choking, cyanosis during feeding, and radiographic evidence of a coiled feeding tube in the proximal esophagus.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a history of recurrent infections, eczema, and easy bruising. Physical examination reveals petechiae and purpura, along with small platelets on blood smear. The child also has a family history of male relatives dying from severe bleeding episodes. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by thrombocytopenia (with small platelets), eczema, and recurrent infections. It follows an X-linked inheritance pattern and shows elevated IgE and IgA with decreased IgM levels.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with inspiratory stridor, a barking cough, and hoarseness. The child has no signs of respiratory distress at rest. What is the most likely causative organism for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Parainfluenza virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Croup, caused by the parainfluenza virus, presents with inspiratory stridor, barking cough, and hoarseness, typically in children under 5 years of age.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens when crying and improves in the prone position. On further examination baby had distress, tachypnea and retractions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laryngomalacia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants, characterized by inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position and improves when prone.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with a history of pneumonia presents with sudden respiratory distress and chest pain. On examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the affected side, and imaging reveals a thin-walled, air-filled cavity within the lung parenchyma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pneumatocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumatocele is a thin-walled, air-filled cavity within the lung parenchyma, often following pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus in children.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic due to recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and greasy, foul-smelling stools. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing and auscultation reveals coarse crackles on lung examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cystic fibrosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis commonly presents with recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and steatorrhea in infants. Sweat chloride test (>60 mEq/L) is the diagnostic hallmark. Pancreatic insufficiency is a major feature contributing to malabsorption and failure to thrive.
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis commonly presents with recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and steatorrhea in infants.
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis
  • ➤ Sweat chloride test (>60 mEq/L) is the diagnostic hallmark.
  • ➤ Sweat chloride test (>60 mEq/L)
  • ➤ Pancreatic insufficiency is a major feature contributing to malabsorption and failure to thrive.
  • ➤ Pancreatic insufficiency

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with respiratory distress. On examination, the infant has tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 70 breaths per minute. What is the most appropriate next step based on the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria for fast breathing in this age group?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administer supplemental oxygen.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In infants with severe respiratory distress (tachypnea >60 breaths/min for age 0–2 months), administering supplemental oxygen is the first and most important step, followed by further diagnostic and therapeutic measures.

questions.text: A 1-year 2 months old child presents with fever and cough. On examination, the respiratory rate is noted to be 50 breaths per minute. According to the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria for fast breathing in this age group, what is the appropriate classification?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pneumonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumonia is classified as fast breathing above the age-specific threshold with or without chest indrawing but without danger signs. Treat with oral amoxicillin for 5 days.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with asthma presents for a follow-up visit. The physician recommends a switch from a nebulizer to a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) for daily maintenance medication. The child's parent expresses concern about proper usage. What key step should be emphasized to ensure effective MDI administration?

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid inhalation after activating the MDI

options.label: B
options.text: Holding the breath for at least 10 seconds after inhalation

options.label: C
options.text: Using a spacer device with the MDI

options.label: D
options.text: Administering a bronchodilator before the corticosteroid MDI

questions.correct_answer: C. Using a spacer device with the MDI
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Using a spacer device with the MDI.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Using a spacer device with an MDI is the most critical step to ensure effective medication delivery in children, especially for those who struggle with coordination during inhaler use.

questions.text: A newborn presents with excessive salivation, choking, and coughing during feeds. Physical examination reveals polyhydramnios, abdominal distension, and a "feeding tube" sign on a chest X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) with esophageal atresia presents with excessive salivation, choking during feeds, a coiled feeding tube on X-ray, and polyhydramnios in utero.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the clinic with sudden, involuntary, nonrhythmic movements of the face and extremities. The child has a history of recent group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Neurological examination reveals choreiform movements, particularly involving the upper limbs and facial muscles. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these neurological manifestations in the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sydenham's chorea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sydenham's chorea is a hallmark neurological manifestation of acute rheumatic fever, occurring as a late autoimmune sequela of group A streptococcal pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, and episodes of irritability during feeding. Physical examination reveals a prominent precordial impulse, a gallop rhythm, and a pansystolic murmur at the left sternal border. Echocardiography demonstrates an anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery. Which of the following congenital heart defects best corresponds to the clinical presentation described in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ALCAPA syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ALCAPA syndrome should be suspected in infants with heart failure, feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, and echocardiographic findings of an anomalous coronary artery originating from the pulmonary artery.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever and a characteristic rash. Physical examination reveals pink, non-pruritic, and serpiginous skin lesions with well-demarcated borders on the trunk and limbs. The lesions tend to migrate and change in shape. Which of the following conditions is associated with the described rash and is commonly seen as a manifestation of a systemic illness in children?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Erythema marginatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema marginatum is a migratory, serpiginous rash associated with acute rheumatic fever and is part of the Jones criteria for diagnosing this systemic illness

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with ductal-dependent congenital heart disease. The medical team plans to initiate prostaglandin therapy to maintain ductal patency. Which of the following medications is commonly used in this context to prevent ductal closure and improve systemic or pulmonary blood flow in critically ill neonates with congenital heart defects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alprostadil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alprostadil (PGE1) is used to maintain ductal patency in neonates with ductal-dependent congenital heart disease, buying time for definitive surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child living in a region with selenium-deficient soil presents with symptoms of cardiomyopathy, including heart failure and arrhythmias. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of selenium. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child, considering the clinical presentation and regional selenium deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Keshan disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keshan disease is an endemic cardiomyopathy caused by selenium deficiency, presenting with dilated cardiomyopathy, heart failure, and arrhythmias in selenium-deficient regions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with cyanosis, clubbing of fingers, and polycythemia. Echocardiography reveals an intracardiac shunt allowing deoxygenated blood to bypass the pulmonary circulation. Which of the following types of cardiac shunts is characterized by the flow of deoxygenated blood from the right side of the heart to the left side, resulting in the systemic circulation receiving poorly oxygenated blood?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tetralogy of Fallot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by a right-to-left shunt, causing systemic hypoxemia, cyanosis, clubbing, and polycythemia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with palpitations and a history of recurrent episodes of rapid heart rate. ECG shows a short PR interval, delta waves, and widened QRS complexes. Which of the following conditions is commonly associated with the described ECG findings, indicating the presence of an accessory pathway that bypasses the atrioventricular node and leads to pre-excitation of the ventricles?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ WPW syndrome is characterized by a short PR interval, delta waves, and widened QRS complexes due to an accessory pathway bypassing the AV node. It commonly presents with palpitations and SVT.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents with exertional dyspnea and fatigue. Physical examination reveals a loud first heart sound, a mid-diastolic murmur, and a widely split second heart sound. Echocardiography confirms the presence of an atrial septal defect and a severely stenosed mitral valve. Which of the following conditions is characterized by the combination of these two cardiac abnormalities, leading to symptoms of pulmonary congestion and right heart volume overload?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lutembacher syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lutembacher syndrome is defined by the coexistence of atrial septal defect (ASD) and mitral stenosis (MS), with ostium secundum being the most common type of ASD associated with this condition.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with severe pulmonary hypertension secondary to left-sided heart disease undergoes a surgical procedure that creates a direct communication between the descending aorta and the left pulmonary artery. Which of the following terms is used to describe this surgical shunt, designed to relieve pulmonary hypertension by redirecting blood flow from the systemic circulation to the pulmonary vasculature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Potts shunt

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Potts shunt is a surgical connection between the descending aorta and the pulmonary artery, used to relieve severe pulmonary hypertension by diverting systemic blood flow to the lungs.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with respiratory distress, dysphagia, and recurrent respiratory infections. Imaging studies reveal a vascular ring compressing the trachea and esophagus. Which of the following congenital anomalies, characterized by the persistence of both the right and left aortic arches, is responsible for the observed clinical presentation, leading to symptoms related to airway and esophageal compression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Double arch of aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Double arch of the aorta is a congenital anomaly where a vascular ring compresses the trachea and esophagus, leading to respiratory distress, dysphagia, and recurrent infections. Surgical correction is the definitive treatment.
  • ➤ Double arch of the aorta

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic due to concerns about the size of the anterior fontanelle. On examination, the fontanelle is found to be large, bulging, and tense, with visible scalp veins. There are no other abnormalities noted. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hydrocephalus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A large, bulging anterior fontanelle with visible scalp veins in an infant is most likely due to hydrocephalus , and the treatment of choice is ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery.
  • ➤ large, bulging anterior fontanelle with visible scalp veins
  • ➤ hydrocephalus
  • ➤ ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her first trimester is seeking advice on preventing neural tube defects (NTDs) in her baby. What is the recommended daily dose of folic acid supplementation for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 400 micrograms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 400 micrograms of folic acid daily is the standard dose recommended for all women of reproductive age to prevent neural tube defects in their babies.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with recurrent headaches, seizures, and focal neurological deficits. Neuroimaging reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the brain parenchyma. Which of the following clinical features is most commonly associated with neurocysticercosis in this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Eosinophilia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eosinophilia is commonly associated with neurocysticercosis and parasitic infections, presenting alongside neurological symptoms such as seizures and focal deficits.

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is brought to the clinic with a protruding sac containing spinal cord and meninges. The sac is covered by a thin membrane, and the infant has paralysis and sensory deficits below the level of the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myelomeningocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myelomeningocele is a form of spina bifida characterized by a protruding sac containing both the spinal cord and meninges, typically associated with neurological deficits.

questions.text: A neonate is born with a large defect in the skull and spine, exposing both the brain and spinal cord without any protective covering. Physical examination reveals no intact skin or membrane overlying the exposed neural tissue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Craniorachischisis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniorachischisis is the most severe form of neural tube defect, involving open defects of both the brain and spinal cord, with no protective covering, leading to the worst prognosis among NTDs.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with macrocephaly and severe developmental delay. Neuroimaging reveals near-total absence of cerebral hemispheres, with only the brainstem and basal ganglia remaining. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydranencephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydranencephaly is defined by the near-total absence of cerebral hemispheres, replaced by CSF, leaving only the brainstem and basal ganglia intact. This condition is associated with macrocephaly and severe developmental delay.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the clinic with facial anomalies, including a single central incisor, closely set eyes, and a flattened nose. Imaging studies reveal a single ventricle and absent septum pellucidum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Holoprosencephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Holoprosencephaly is characterized by incomplete separation of the cerebral hemispheres and associated midline facial anomalies, such as a single central incisor, hypotelorism, and flattened or absent nose.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with developmental delay, seizures, and macrocephaly. Imaging studies demonstrate ventriculomegaly, and further evaluation reveals aqueductal stenosis. What additional feature is commonly associated with aqueductal stenosis in this clinical context?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Corpus callosum agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corpus callosum agenesis is a key feature commonly associated with aqueductal stenosis and should be recognized in clinical contexts of ventriculomegaly and developmental delay.

questions.text: A neonate is admitted with a rapidly increasing head circumference, poor feeding, and irritability. On examination, there is a bulging fontanelle and McEwan sign is elicited. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neuroimaging – Transcranial USG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transcranial ultrasound is the investigation of choice for hydrocephalus, intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and neonatal seizures in neonates, making it an essential tool in the evaluation of rapidly increasing head circumference and bulging fontanelle.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with a rapidly increasing head circumference, congestive heart failure, and a prominent pulsatile mass on the fontanelle. Imaging reveals a dilated midline vessel. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vein of Galen malformation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vein of Galen malformation is a congenital vascular anomaly that presents with a rapidly increasing head circumference, congestive heart failure, and a prominent pulsatile fontanelle. Imaging reveals a dilated midline vessel.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl develops profuse, foul-smelling diarrhea after ingesting contaminated water during a camping trip. Stool analysis shows cysts with a classic "teardrop" appearance. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's parasitic diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Albendazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Albendazole is the first-line treatment for parasitic diarrhea caused by Giardia lamblia in children, with a dosage of 200 mg for children under 2 years and 400 mg for those 2 years or older.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with acute diarrhea is prescribed zinc supplementation as part of the management plan. What is the recommended daily dose of elemental zinc for the treatment of acute diarrhea in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20 mg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For children aged 6 months and older with acute diarrhea, the recommended daily dose of elemental zinc is 20 mg for 10–14 days.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with irritability, poor weight gain, and frequent regurgitation after feeds. The mother reports that the infant arches the back and cries during feeding. What is the most likely diagnosis for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sandifer Syndrome is a complication of GERD in infants, characterized by arching of the back during feeding, frequent regurgitation, and irritability. GERD should be suspected in cases with poor weight gain and regurgitation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is evaluated for recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, and intermittent diarrhea. She reports discomfort after consuming wheat-based products. Serologic testing reveals elevated anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA). What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this child's suspected celiac disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen breath test for lactose intolerance

questions.correct_answer: A. Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease. Look for scalloping of duodenal folds and confirm histopathologic findings using the Marsh-Oberhuber classification.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is evaluated for recurrent episodes of regurgitation of undigested food without associated pain or discomfort. The symptoms occur at least twice a week for the past three months. What is the most likely diagnosis based on Rome's criteria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rumination disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rumination disorder is characterized by effortless regurgitation of undigested food, occurring without pain, nausea, or retching, and is diagnosed using Rome IV criteria.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to the presence of multiple gastrointestinal polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation, including perioral freckling. Family history reveals a similar condition in the father. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child based on these clinical features?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by mucocutaneous pigmentation (e.g., perioral freckling) and gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is admitted with severe dehydration due to acute gastroenteritis. What is the appropriate concentration of potassium in oral rehydration solution (ORS) for the initial management of this child's dehydration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The standard potassium concentration in ORS for managing dehydration in children is 20 mEq/L, as per WHO guidelines.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with SAM is admitted with severe dehydration, and the healthcare team plans to initiate rehydration using RESOMAL. What is the potassium concentration in Resomal, a solution commonly used for rehydration in pediatric patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 40 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RESOMAL contains 40 mEq/L of potassium, making it specifically tailored for managing dehydration in children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

questions.text: A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg is admitted for observation. According to the Holliday and Segar formula, what is the appropriate daily maintenance fluid requirement for this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1600 mL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For children, the Holliday and Segar formula provides a stepwise method for calculating daily maintenance fluids: 100 mL/kg for the first 10 kg, 50 mL/kg for the next 10 kg, and 20 mL/kg for any weight above 20 kg. Thus, the total daily fluid requirement for this child is

questions.text: A newborn is suspected to have tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) due to excessive salivation, choking during feeds, and a polyhydramnios history. Which type of TEF may be indicative, considering the absence of air in the abdomen on X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) type A, B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the absence of air in the abdomen on X-ray, types A and B TEFs (no communication between the esophagus and the trachea) are the most likely diagnoses.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a pruritic rash consisting of erythematous macules that progress to vesicles and then form pustules. The lesions are in different stages of development and are concentrated on the trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the characteristic rash?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Varicella (Chickenpox)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Varicella is characterized by a pruritic rash with lesions in different stages of development, primarily concentrated on the trunk.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of fever, headache. On examination, the child has a tender, swollen jaw. There is no evidence of skin rash. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mumps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mumps is characterized by fever, headache, and tender swelling of the parotid glands (parotitis). Aseptic meningitis is the most common complication of mumps .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, cough, and conjunctivitis. Serological testing reveals a specific viral infection, and histopathological examination of lymphoid tissue shows the presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Measles (Rubeola)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are a pathognomonic finding in measles (Rubeola). Recognize the key symptoms of measles: fever, cough, conjunctivitis, coryza, and rash, to make a clinical diagnosis efficiently.
  • ➤ Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are a pathognomonic finding in measles (Rubeola).

questions.text: Match the infectious disease with its corresponding incubation period: Measles (Rubeola) Varicella (Chickenpox) Syphilis Mumps 10-21 days 2-4 weeks 8-12 days 9-90 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-3, B-1, C4-, D-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The incubation periods of infectious diseases:
  • ➤ The incubation periods of infectious diseases:
  • ➤ Measles: 8-12 days. Varicella: 10-21 days. Syphilis: 9-90 days. Mumps: 2-4 weeks.
  • ➤ Measles: 8-12 days.
  • ➤ Varicella: 10-21 days.
  • ➤ Syphilis: 9-90 days.
  • ➤ Mumps: 2-4 weeks.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a fever, oral ulcers, and a rash with vesicles on the hands, feet, and buttocks. On examination, there is no itching or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is characterized by vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and buttocks along with oral ulcers, and is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus A16 or Enterovirus 71.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a fever, cough, and the presence of small, discrete white spots on the buccal mucosa. The spots are surrounded by a red halo. The child is otherwise well, with no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Measles (Rubeola)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koplik spots are pathognomonic for measles (Rubeola) and appear as small, discrete white spots with a red halo on the buccal mucosa.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a fever and a rash that starts on the cheeks, resembling a "slapped cheek." Subsequently, the rash becomes more widespread, involving the trunk and extremities, with a lacy pattern. What is the most likely causative organism of this infectious disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parvovirus B19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Slapped cheek" rash with a subsequent lacy rash on the trunk and extremities is characteristic of erythema infectiosum, caused by Parvovirus B19.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of high fever for several days. On examination, there is a sudden onset of a maculopapular rash spreading from the trunk to the extremities. "Rose-pink" lesions are noted on the soft palate. What is the most likely causative organism of this infectious disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nagayama spots (rose-pink lesions on the soft palate) and a sudden maculopapular rash following high fever are hallmark features of Roseola Infantum, caused by Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6).

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a circular, erythematous rash with central clearing on the thigh. The child recently returned from a camping trip. There are no systemic symptoms, and the rash is painless. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Empirical antibiotic therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema Migrans (a circular, erythematous rash with central clearing) is an early sign of Lyme disease. Immediate empirical antibiotic therapy is essential to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with joint pain and swelling, along with a history of a circular rash with central clearing on the arm a few weeks ago. The child had recently spent time in an area with tall grass. What is the most likely cause of the joint symptoms, and what would be the most appropriate diagnostic test?

options.label: A
options.text: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA); Anti-nuclear Antibody (ANA) test

questions.correct_answer: B. Lyme Disease; Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lyme Disease; Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Joint pain and swelling after a history of Erythema Migrans in a child suggest Lyme disease. ELISA for Borrelia-specific antibodies is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with recurrent febrile episodes despite appropriate treatment for Plasmodium vivax malaria. What is the most likely reason for the recurrence, and what additional therapy may be required to prevent further relapses?

options.label: A
options.text: Persistent blood-stage infection; Artemisinin-based combination therapy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypnozoites; Primaquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent febrile episodes in Plasmodium vivax malaria are caused by hypnozoites, the dormant liver stage of the parasite. Primaquine is the definitive therapy to prevent relapses.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to an abnormal head shape. On examination, there is a triangular-shaped forehead with a prominent ridge along the metopic suture. The head is narrow and elongated, with a pointed appearance. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trigonocephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trigonocephaly is characterized by a triangular-shaped forehead and a prominent ridge along the metopic suture, caused by premature closure of the metopic suture.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. On examination, the head circumference is found to be significantly smaller than the 3rd percentile, while the height and weight are at the 50th percentile. The infant demonstrates irritability and increased muscle tone. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Microcephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microcephaly is defined by a head circumference below the 3rd percentile and is often associated with neurological abnormalities such as irritability and increased muscle tone.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for a routine examination. On palpation, the physician identifies a soft spot on the infant's skull located at the intersection of the frontal and parietal bones. Which of the following terms best describes the precise location of this soft spot in the infant's skull?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bregma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bregma is the soft spot (anterior fontanelle) located at the intersection of the frontal and parietal bones in infants, allowing for brain growth during early development.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to concerns about his growth and development. Physical examination reveals macrocephaly, a prominent jaw, and a pointed chin. His height and weight are both above the 97th percentile for his age, and he has advanced bone age. The child's developmental milestones are appropriate for his age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sotos syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sotos syndrome is characterized by overgrowth (height and weight >97th percentile), macrocephaly, a prominent jaw, a pointed chin, and advanced bone age, with developmental milestones typically appropriate for age.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with downward slanting eyes, absence of lower eyelashes, and bilateral external ear anomalies characterized by hypoplastic, malformed, or absent pinnae. The child also has a small mandible and cleft palate. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Treacher Collins syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treacher Collins syndrome is characterized by downward slanting eyes, absence of lower eyelashes, malformed or absent pinnae, small mandible, and cleft palate, caused by genetic mutations affecting craniofacial development.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her first trimester with a history of neural tube defects (NTDs) in a previous pregnancy is seeking guidance on folic acid supplementation. What is the recommended daily dose of folic acid supplementation for this high-risk population?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4000 micrograms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pregnant women with a history of neural tube defects in a previous pregnancy, the recommended dose of folic acid supplementation is 4000 micrograms (4 mg) daily, starting before conception and continuing through the first trimester.

questions.text: During a routine developmental assessment, a 3-year-old child's Gesell Developmental Schedule yields a developmental quotient (DQ) of 100. What is the most appropriate interpretation of this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Normal development

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A developmental quotient (DQ) of 100 signifies normal development, with the child’s developmental and chronological ages being equivalent.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a routine check-up. On examination, his height is noted to have doubled since birth. What is the most likely interpretation of this finding?
questions.correct_answer: B. Normal growth trajectory for a 4-year-old
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Normal growth trajectory for a 4-year-old.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A child’s height typically doubles by 4 years of age and triples by 12 years. This finding represents normal growth trajectory.

questions.text: A 2-week-old newborn is brought for a well-baby check-up. On examination, the pediatrician notes a small, diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle. What is the most likely cause of the fontanelle's appearance in this healthy newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Normal variation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A small, diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle is a normal anatomical variation in healthy newborns and does not indicate any underlying pathology.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician, and the parents express concern about the soft spot on the baby's head. In a newborn, how many fontanelles are typically present?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Six

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Newborns have six fontanelles: one anterior, one posterior, two mastoid, and two sphenoidal. These fontanelles allow for skull flexibility and brain growth during infancy.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician, and the parents inquire about the appearance of the baby's first teeth. Which of the following sets of temporary teeth is most likely to have erupted or be in the process of erupting in this infant?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lower Central incisors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lower central incisors are the first primary teeth to erupt, typically around 6-7 months of age.

questions.text: A 15-month-old toddler is brought to the pediatrician for a developmental check-up. The parents express concerns about the child's brain development. The pediatrician explains that by the age of 2, approximately what percentage of the child's brain growth is expected to be completed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 85% - 90%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By the age of 2, approximately 85-90% of a child’s brain growth is completed, emphasizing the importance of the first two years for optimal developmental outcomes.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is referred for evaluation of short stature. Physical examination reveals normal growth parameters, and bone age assessment indicates delayed skeletal maturation. Laboratory tests rule out endocrine abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child's short stature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Constitutional growth delay

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Constitutional growth delay is the most common cause of short stature with delayed skeletal maturation. Bone age is less than chronological age, and children eventually achieve normal adult height.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with disproportionately short limbs compared to the trunk. Physical examination reveals a prominent forehead and a flattened mid-face. Which of the following genetic disorders is most likely responsible for this short limb dwarfism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Achondroplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Achondroplasia is the most common cause of disproportionate short-limb dwarfism, characterized by a prominent forehead, flattened mid-face, and a mutation in the FGFR3 gene.
